procedure: Left Total Hip Replacement for intracapsular displaced femoral neck fracture
Negative pressure incisional wound therapy <50 sq cm

extracted_info.summary: 88-year-old male with left femoral neck hip fracture after a mechanical fall. Patient has preexisting osteoarthritis of the left hip. Plan is for left total hip replacement. Patient has multiple comorbidities including HTN, HLD, CAD s/p MI with stents, CKD stage 3, anemia, IBS, and aortic stenosis.
diagnosis: History of myocardial infarction with stents
Acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease
key_information: Patient sustained injury from mechanical fall in CVS parking lot
Patient has 30% mortality risk in 1 year due to comorbidities
Patient requires medical optimization and clearance before surgery
Non-weight bearing on left lower extremity
Patient has preexisting degenerative joint disease
Patient has CKD with AKI requiring risk stratification
Patient is allergic to Augmentin
Patient is a former smoker with current alcohol use
Patient has been consented for surgery with family present

procedure: Left Total Hip Replacement for intracapsular displaced femoral neck fracture
Negative pressure incisional wound therapy <50 sq cm
extracted_info.summary: 88-year-old male presented with a displaced femoral neck fracture of the left hip following a fall, requiring a total hip replacement. The procedure involved a cemented femoral component with a 36mm head and a size 50 acetabular component. Patient has elevated risk factors including obesity, AKI on CKD, and high infection risk, necessitating negative pressure wound therapy. The patient was cleared for weight bearing as tolerated with DVT prophylaxis and extended antibiotic coverage for infection prevention.

full_source.description: Tenodesis of biceps tendon for labral tear/biceps tendon pathology with specific range of motion and physical exam requirements (Evidence: pg no: 10, L408-L437)
full_source.scope: Arthroscopic or open biceps tenodesis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L408)

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 10, L410-L412)

Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration, except for discrete traumatic event resulting in acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L413-L416)

Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) demonstrates labral tear/biceps tendon pathology (e.g., SLAP, Bankart, full-thickness subscapularis tear) and correlates with symptoms and physical exam findings (Evidence: pg no: 10, L417-L420)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain, cervical radiculopathy, and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L421-L423)
Minimally limited or full shoulder range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 10, L426)

ONE OR MORE positive physical exam findings including O'Brien's Test, Biceps Load Test, Clunk Test, Anterior Slide Test, Compression Rotation Test, Speed's Test, Upper cut test, Popeye sign, Yergason's test, Proximal biceps (groove) tenderness (Evidence: pg no: 10, L427-L437)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 10, L439-L440)

codes.description: Tenodesis of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 13, L545)

full_source.notes: Conservative management exception for acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L414-L416)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)

Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

ORTHOPAEDICS & REHABILITATION

Patient name: Morris Mondschein

Yale MRN: MR674177

Date of birth: 3/27/1937

Date of visit: 11/22/2025

Attending of record for this patient: Delos, Demetris, MD
Provider leaving this note: Michael B Held, MD

Reason for consult: Left hip fracture

History of present illness:

Morris Mondschein is a 88 y.o. male with PMHX HTN, HLD, former smoker, CAD s/p MI with stents, CKD stage 3,
anemia, IBS aortic stenosis who presents s/p mechanical fall with left hip pain and inability to ambulate. At baseline
the patient ambulates without assistive device. He states he fell in the parking lot of CVS after tripping on a wooden
object. He was able to get up and drive after the fall, but when he got home he could not enter his house so he called

911. He did hit his head, but no LOC.

Orthopedic Surgery Operative Report

Patient Name: Morris Mondschein
Date of Procedure: 11/22/2025
Location: Greenwich Hospital
MRN: MR674177

Procedure:
1) Left Total Hip Replacement for intracapsular displaced femoral neck fracture
2) Negative pressure incisional wound therapy <50 sq cm

Suggested cpt codes: 27130, 97605

Preliminary Diagnosis: Displaced femoral neck fracture of the Left hip
Postoperative Diagnosis : Same

Surgeon: Dr. Michael B Held

First Assist: Anne Hall, RNFA

Of note, a first assist PA was necessary for this procedure, as no other first assist or resident was available to help
due to the complex nature of the surgery.

PA assisted with exposure, trialing and implantation, and closure of the wound

Anesthesia Staff: No anesthesia staff entered.
Anesthesia Type: Failed Spinal, converted to general

Specimens:
Femoral Head

Estimated Blood Loss:
200

Implants:
* No implants in log *

Findings: Displaced femoral neck fracture

Indication:

The patient is a 88 y.o. male who presented to our emergency room after a fall and was found to have a left hip
displaced femoral neck fracture. Femur fractures in the elderly are of the highest severity due to the morbidity without
treatment and risk of death due to bed-ridden disability, risk of ulcers, and risk of clot and other medical complications
causing death. Therefore | had a long discussion with the patient and their family about the treatment options,
including nonoperative and operative intervention. We discussed risks and benefits and alternatives to surgery as
well as chances of full or partial weight bearing after. We discussed the risks of surgery including infection, wound
complications, bleeding, need for a transfusion, possible damage to surronding neurovascular structures, potential for
continued pain, continued weakness, worsening pain and worsening weakness, stiffness, instability/dislocation, limb
length discrepancy, fracture, infection requiring the resection or revision arthroplasty, component loosening and the
need for revision surgery in the future. We also discussed the risks of thromboembolic complications, stroke, heart
attack, cardiac event, heart failure, pulmonary edema, fat embolus, aspiration, death, and the risks of anesthesia.
The potential benefits of surgery are pain relief or improvement, improved mobility, and allowance of immediate
weight bearing post-operatively. We also discussed some of the risks specific to the anterior approach including
numbness over the lateral thigh, wound complications, and femoral component loosening or fracture of the femur.
These risks were discussed in the context of other approaches, specifically the posterior approach and its associated
risks. The patient expressed an understanding of these risks and the patient wished to proceed with a total hip
replacement. We discussed his elevated risk of mortality, infection and needing dialysis due to his AKI on CKD.

We also discussed the overall poor prognosis for patients who have suffered a femur fracture, with high morbidity and
Mondschein, Morris (MRN MR674177) Printed by Stagno, Cesarina [767] at 11/24/2025 8:20 AM 1/3

11/24/25, 8:20 AM Mondschein, Morris (MR # MR674177) DOB: 03/27/1937

mortality rates following this particular pattern of injury. The patient and family expressed understanding and elected
to proceed with a total hip replacement.

The patient was seen by the Medicine service and was determined to be optimized from a medical standpoint for this
surgery. The medicine team cleared the patient for surgery as well.

Description of procedure:
The patient was seen in the preoperative holding area and the appropriate side lower extremity was marked. Again a
discussion of the procedure was held with the patient and the patient wished to proceed.

The patient was brought to the Operating Room and a preliminary anesthesia time out was then performed. General
anesthesia was then performed by the anesthesia team. The patient was then placed supine on the operating room
table. Preoperative antibiotics were administered within thirty minutes of incision time as well as 1 gram of tranexamic
acid. The patient was placed onto a sacral bump on the operating room table. At this point, the patient’s surgical area
was prepped and draped in the standard, sterile fashion. A surgical timeout was then performed to confirm the correct
side, procedure, and name.

A longitudinal incision was made starting lateral and distal to the anterior superior iliac spine. The incision was
carried down through the subcutaneous tissues down to the level of the tensor fascia lata. The tensor fascia lata was
then divided sharply with care not to violate the muscle below. Blunt dissection of the fascia was done to identify the
interval between the tensor fascia lata and the sartorius. Once this was done and deeper retractors had been placed,
the ascending branch of the lateral femoral circumflex artery was clearly visualized and this was cauterized. Next, the
fat within this interval was dissected to better visualize the anterior hip capsule and the lateral border of the
iliocapsularis. At this point, a Cobb was used to elevate the iliocapsularis and rectus off the anterior capsule and a
retractor was placed underneath these muscles. At this point, a capsulectomy was performed along the axis of the
femoral neck and the intertrochanteric ridge. A large hemarthrosis from the fracture was encountered. The retractors
were now placed intracapsular and the head-neck junction was exposed. A release of the pubofemoral ligament was
then performed until the lesser trochanter could be palpated. Using the pre-operative templating, the appropriate
clean up neck cut was made and the femoral head and remaining neck was extracted.

The acetabulum was now visualized with the placement of retractors. At this point, the labrum and the contents of the
cotyloid fossa were removed. The acetabulum was then reamed sequentially, based on preoperative templating.
Reaming was performed carefully. Next, the final size 50 acetabular component was impacted into the appropriate
position. The periphery of the acetabular component was inspected and any osteophytes were removed. Once this
was accomplished, the final 36mm neutral polyethylene liner was impacted into place. Care was taken to ensure that
the liner was fully seated and had engaged the locking mechanism.

Next, the acetabular retractors were removed and attention was turned to the femur. The leg was positioned in an
adducted and extended position. Retractors were then placed around the proximal femur to expose the cut neck
surface. Tight capsular tissue over the superior/anterior aspect of the femoral neck was released using cautery only
to allow for sufficient exposure. A curved double footed retractor was placed over the greater trochanter laterally and
a femoral retractor placed at the infero medial neck. Sequential releases were performed in order to allow for
accepted elevation of the femur, this was done in conjunction with gentle elevation with a bone hook.

The canal finder was then used to establish the IM canal. A box cutter was used to remove posterolateral bone of the
cut neck. Arasp and curette were used to remove lateral femoral neck bone remaining. An entry broach was
utilized, followed by sequential broaching up to the final size. With the broach left in place and after calcar planning,
the neck and trials were placed. The hip was reduced and found to be stable. Leg length, offset and implant size and
position were assessed clinically. Afterwards, the hip was dislocated. The trial components were removed.

The femoral canal was irrigated and a cement restrictor was placed down the canal. The canal was again rinsed and
dried. Cement was then placed in the canal and pressurized, and the final size 1std stem was placed in the canal.
After the cement hardened the actual 36mm +0 head was now impacted into place after cleaning and drying. The hip
was reduced with traction and internal rotation after confirming that the acetabular component was free of any debris
and had been irrigated.

The wound was then copiously irrigated and washed with a dilute betadine solution then with normal saline. Copious
irrigation was used throughout the closure. 1 gram of Vancomycin powder was placed in the deep wound. The
fascia overlying the TFL was now closed using running barbed suture, with care to not entrap any of the lateral
femoral cutaneous nerve branches. The remainder of the wound was closed in layers using #1 Vicryl, 2-0 Vicryl, and
staples for skin. Incisional negative pressure wound therapy <50sq cm was used due to his obesity, ckd and high
risk for infection

SN redapt/polarstem cemented components were used in this procedure.

improvements.original: Basic plan without structured medical necessity documentation
improvements.improved: Comprehensive structured plan with specific medical necessity documentation section
improvements.reason: Explicit documentation of medical necessity criteria supports coverage determination

improvements.improved: Added structured postoperative care plan section with placeholders for physician input
improvements.reason: Documentation of comprehensive care planning demonstrates appropriate resource utilization and continuity of care

user_input_required.reason: Pain severity, character, and impact documentation is required to establish medical necessity for surgical intervention
user_input_required.suggestion: Document pain severity on 0-10 scale, character of pain (sharp, dull, etc.), aggravating/alleviating factors, and functional limitations

user_input_required.reason: Baseline functional status is critical for establishing medical necessity and expected outcomes
user_input_required.suggestion: Document living situation, independence with activities of daily living, mobility status, and use of assistive devices prior to injury

user_input_required.reason: Comprehensive neurovascular assessment is required to document pre-surgical status and medical necessity
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific motor strength grading (0-5 scale) for key muscle groups and detailed sensory examination

user_input_required.reason: Detailed imaging findings are required to support medical necessity for total hip arthroplasty versus hemiarthroplasty
user_input_required.suggestion: Document fracture classification (Garden classification), degree of displacement, and detailed description of preexisting osteoarthritis

user_input_required.field: Postoperative weight-bearing status and rehabilitation protocol
user_input_required.reason: Comprehensive postoperative planning demonstrates appropriate resource utilization and continuity of care
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific weight-bearing status, timeline for progression, and anticipated rehabilitation protocol

user_input_required.reason: Documentation of thromboembolic risk management is required for surgical procedures
user_input_required.suggestion: Specify planned postoperative DVT prophylaxis medication, duration, and monitoring

recommendations.recommendation: Document specific pain severity on 0-10 scale and functional limitations to establish medical necessity
Document specific fracture classification (Garden) and detailed description of preexisting osteoarthritis to support total hip arthroplasty versus hemiarthroplasty decision
Create explicit medical necessity section documenting why total hip arthroplasty is preferred over hemiarthroplasty for this specific patient
Document comprehensive postoperative care plan including weight-bearing status, DVT prophylaxis, and rehabilitation protocol

compliance_impact.before: The original consultation note lacked structured documentation of medical necessity for total hip arthroplasty versus hemiarthroplasty. Pain assessment was minimal, and specific radiographic findings supporting the surgical approach were not detailed. The note also lacked a comprehensive postoperative care plan.
compliance_impact.after: The improved chart includes explicit medical necessity documentation supporting total hip arthroplasty for femoral neck fracture with preexisting osteoarthritis. With physician input for the identified missing elements, the chart will provide comprehensive documentation of pain assessment, detailed radiographic findings, and a complete postoperative care plan that meets payer requirements.
key_changes: Added structured medical necessity documentation section
Created explicit justification for total hip arthroplasty versus hemiarthroplasty
Added pain assessment section with placeholders for severity and character
Structured past medical history to highlight relevant comorbidities
Added comprehensive postoperative care plan section
Requested specific radiographic findings to support surgical approach

extraction_data.summary: 88-year-old male with left femoral neck hip fracture after a mechanical fall. Patient has preexisting osteoarthritis of the left hip. Plan is for left total hip replacement. Patient has multiple comorbidities including HTN, HLD, CAD s/p MI with stents, CKD stage 3, anemia, IBS, and aortic stenosis.
diagnosis: History of myocardial infarction with stents
Acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease
key_information: Patient sustained injury from mechanical fall in CVS parking lot
Patient has 30% mortality risk in 1 year due to comorbidities
Patient requires medical optimization and clearance before surgery
Non-weight bearing on left lower extremity
Patient has preexisting degenerative joint disease
Patient has CKD with AKI requiring risk stratification
Patient is allergic to Augmentin
Patient is a former smoker with current alcohol use
Patient has been consented for surgery with family present

procedure: Left Total Hip Replacement for intracapsular displaced femoral neck fracture
Negative pressure incisional wound therapy <50 sq cm
extraction_data.summary: 88-year-old male presented with a displaced femoral neck fracture of the left hip following a fall, requiring a total hip replacement. The procedure involved a cemented femoral component with a 36mm head and a size 50 acetabular component. Patient has elevated risk factors including obesity, AKI on CKD, and high infection risk, necessitating negative pressure wound therapy. The patient was cleared for weight bearing as tolerated with DVT prophylaxis and extended antibiotic coverage for infection prevention.

procedure: Left Total Hip Replacement for intracapsular displaced femoral neck fracture
Negative pressure incisional wound therapy <50 sq cm
